div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS.
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.
Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRÆUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE. In connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.
PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).
RED SEA LINE.

Steamers leave Suez weekly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for Port Sudan and Suakin direct returning from Suakin every Wednesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m. a steamer leaves Suez for Jeddah continuing every other week for Suakin, Massowah, Hodeidah, Aden. Intermediate steamers do not proceed beyond beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company's Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.

div.head: LORD MILNER.
div.p: Lord Milner has received many flattering proofs since his return to England of the regard in which he is held by his fellow-countrymen. They have not forgotten, and they will not forgot, his inestimable services to the Empire, and they have testified their admiration by presenting him with an address, which both for the number and the quality of its signatures is without a parallel in political history. The paltry and spiteful attempt which was made to get the House of Commons to pass an oblique vote of censure upon him simply excited the scorn of all honourable men throughout the Empire, and we do not doubt that it helped to ensure the success of the address from the Cape Colony which was presented to Lord Milner last week An influential deputation came all the way from South Africa to assure him that twenty-five thousand signatories in the Cape Colony alone are true to the great principles for which he worked unflinchingly in face of the most for. midable obstacles, those principles being "the gradual fusion of the white races of South Africa into one nation, and the retention of that nation as a permanent member of the British group of States." Sir Lewis Michell said that he had never found him other than "calm and collected and inflexibly resolute to see that by no act of his the British flag should be trailed in the dust." Lord Milner no longer holds any official position ; his influence consists solely of the weight which attaches to the opinions expressed in his speeches, and their general tenor conveys a grave warning. From his place in the House of Lords he has delivered at least two most important speeches, the first soon after he took his place in that Assembly, the latter as recently as July 31, when the Government announced the terms on which they had decided to grant a Constitution to the Transvaal. Some people, it is well known, take pleasure in prophesying evil; the raven's croak in their natural voice. It is not so, however, with Lord Milner If he had been a pessimist he could never have lived through the arduous year. from 1898 to 1904, and kept the firm faith which he always professed in the future of South Africa. It would be much more gratifying to him to believe that things were going well as, indeed, they were, until this Govern. ment came into power and started their policy of meddling and muddling in South African. affairg-in Natal as in the Transvaal. Lord Milner devoted most of his speech yesterday not to any specific act of the Government, such as the new Constitution, nor yet to any of the great problems of South Africa in which British interests have been jeopardised by those who now have the deciding voice at home. He holds that the most pressing dánger of the moment in South Africa is disunion among the British Colonists, who seem ready on the very eve of the first electoral trial of strength to split into groups over merely personal differences, in face of a united Dutch party, which preaches incessantly a Dutch South Africa. But the danger of the moment at home is even greater, for it is the growth of what Lord Milner called the spirit of antinationalism. This is a subject to which we have often referred in these columns, since it is constantly breaking out in new forms and varieties, the only constant symptom being the inveterate belief that in any political quarrel one's own countrymen must be in the wrong.

An Englishman has only to cross the seas, and in the view of those who suffer from this strange "disease of opinion” he changes his nature as well as his sky. With the mind of the pro-Boer during the war everyone was painfully familiar. In some the malady reached the stage of delirium, and drove them to say that, the Boer cause triumphed, they would he to reconsider their belief in Providence. Perhaps the policy of the present Government may spare them such reconsidera. tion, if they have not already performed that mental exercise, for to give away what we have won by hard fighting and vast sacrifices seems to be the ambition of a powerful section of Ministers. Lord Milner spoke of the extraordinary venom which is displayed against any South African who takes the British side in the conflict between British and Dutch ideals, between what was Milnerism and what Krug ism. The Little Englanders condemn him one who must be "animated by the meant sentiments, a tool of capitalists, a soulle, subservient creature, who can have no higher motive than the greed of gold." These are of the same kidney as the pessimists against whom the German Emperor was moved to lift up his voice in strong irritation a week or two ago, when he lamented that they would not relieve the unfortunate Fatherland of their presence. But the German anti-nationalists are tyros compared with the British. Ours are quite unapproachable for their mischievous persistence. How they filled the air with falsehoods about Chinese slavery is notorious --that was perhaps, their greatest achieve ment, for it was a masterpiece of mendacious hypocrisy. Then a pro-Zulu agitation was started, which would have swollen to ten times its dimensions had a Unionist Government been in power, and the anti-nationalist Press grew eloquent over hypothetical outrages. The outcry against the punishment of the Egyptian villagers who set upon and murdered some British officers has hardly yet died away. Lord Cromer's measured warning to the Home Government of the growth of a fanatic anti-British agitation in Egypt is either derided by these "anti-nationalists” or it is accepted as natural and worthy of all sympathy. The wrongs of India, again, are wringing their bosoms. Englishmen are accused of bleeding India tɔ death and of intensifying the poverty of her poorest classes. The Bengali agitators find ready champions here at home. Their seditious songs are carefully explained away as harmless ebullitions by a small but pertinacious group of Anglo-Indians, whose patronage of the Congress movement, and tolerance of the Swadeshi agitation, bid fair to cause really serious trouble in Bengal, where the success of their noisy clamour has alarmed the great Mohammedan section of the population. We do not believe that this antinationalism, as Lord Milner calls it, is popular with the mass of Englishmen, but it is unquestionably popular with the Radical pulpiteer, and with the Trade Union leaders, who are, for the most part, strongly anti-Imperialist. They carry their followers with them much further than the latter wish to go, and they do so the more light-heartedly, because of their exceedingly limited acquaintance with the affairs of any part of the Empire but their own. There will, as Lord Milner said, be a "tremendous rally" when these pernicious doctrines are pushed too || far; but before the rally comes, mischief may be done which can only be eradicated very slowly and at enormous cost.
("Daily Telegraph.")

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: Two deaths from plague occurred in hospital yesterday, viz, one at Alexandria and one at Suez.

div.head: Telephone for Fayoum City
div.p: It is announced that a company has applied for permission to lay a telephone line in Fayoum city.

div.head: The Minleh Show
div.p: The preparations for the agricultural show which is to be held at Minieh next month have already commenced.

div.head: Shoubrah Tragedy
div.p: It is announced that M. Paillard senior has been definitely placed "hors de cause" in reference to the Shoubrah crime.

div.head: Khedivial Law School
div.p: 102 candidates have been admitted to the Khedivial School of Law, 107 for the English and 55 for the French section.

div.head: Crime in Cairo
div.p: During the 24 hours ending at midday on Thursday, 7 thefts. 12 délits and contraventions were reported from Cairo.

div.head: European Lady Run Over
div.p: On Thursday night a European lady was run down by a carriage in the Opera Square. Her injuries were luckily slight. The driver was taken to the Abdin caracol.

div.head: Mr. de Cuerville's Paper
div.p: It is appointed by a contemporary that Mr. de Guerville has found it necessary to give up the ides, for the present at any rate, of publishing a daily newspaper in Cairo on account of ill health.

div.head: The Slollla
div.p: The transport Sicilia with the 3rd Battalion of the Coldstream Guards is due at Alexandria vory shortly, and the men are expected to arrive at their quarters at Abbassieh Bar. racks on Thursday next.

div.head: Coal Imports.
div.p: Between January 1 and October 4, the total imports of coal amounted to 962,958 tona, made up of 522,533 tons Welsh, 154,480 toost Newcastle, 91,317 tons Scotch, 141,150 tons Yorkshire, and 45,278 tons other qualities. Last year's total for the same period was 824,296 tons.

div.head: The Alhambra Theatre.
div.p: The Fantoche Zane will reappear at the Alhambra Theatre this evening with a newly arranged programme. Tomorrow afternoon there will be a matinée, commencing at half past four. On Thursday the Novelli operetta troupe will re-open, for which occasion Sardou's Odette is billed.

div.head: The Ministries.
div.p: Ibrahim Pasha Fogad, Minister of Justice, will return to Cairo tomorrow in company with that portion of the staff which has passed the sommer in Alexandria. The Ministry of 1 Finance has been re-transferred to Cairo. Nobari Bey Innes has postponed his departure for Cairo until the 10th inst.

div.head: The Native Press.
div.p: Sheikh Ahmed el-Guirgawi, the proprietor of the vernacular journal, "El-Irohad,” has been 1 threatening Sheikh Mohamed el Cherbetli, editor-in-chief of "Al Omma," and the latter brought an action against his confrère, who failed to pat in an appearance and has been sentenced to eight months' imprisonment.

div.head: Khedivial Agricultural Society.
div.p: We congratulate the Khedivial Agricultural Society on the excellent appearance of it. Year Book, which is illustrated and printed in a manner that reflects great credit on the National Printing Press at Boulac. The articles in the Year Book are of great interest and importance and we hope in the near future to be able to give our readers a summary of their contents.

div.head: Suez Canal
div.p: On October 4, 13 vessels, of which 5 were northward and 8 southward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 336,916.79. Of these 3 were British, 2 German, 2 Japanese, 2 Russian, 1 Austrian, 1 French, 1 Danish, and 1 Datch. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 1,006,035.78 and during that time 38 vessels transited the Canal, 14 being northward, and 24 southward bound.

Applications will be received free of charge, from clerks and others wishing to obtain posts in egypt. Addrego, Secretary, British Chamber of Commerce, Alexandria. (Advt.].

div.head:
THE KHEDIVE.
TANTAH AGRICULTURAL SHOW.
div.p: The Khedive arrived at Ras el Tin Palace from Montazah this morning, and held his first reception since his return from Borope, which was largely attended.

Hassan Pasba Radwan, Mudir of Garbieh, in the name of the Moudirieh, Ibrahim Pasha Said, on behalf of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, and Mr. George Dominick, in the name of the Tantah Municipality, will be received by the Khedive at Ras el Tin palace, when they will pray for him to preside at the opening of the Tantah Agricultural Show. We under. stand that his Highness will be graciously pleased to accept, and he will leave for Tantah by special train on Thursday, arriving at 10. 45 a.m. and will be accompanied by the Ministers.

His Highness will be received with a salute of 21 guns, and will drive direct to Abmedi Mosque to visit the tomb of Sidi Abmed el Bedawi. He will then proceed to the mosque which has been erected between Birket Bey house and the new criminal courts, after which he will lunch on the Show ground. The guests for the lunch number one hundred including the Ministers, the mudirs, members of the Khedivial Agricultural Society, Legislative Council, and Tantah Municipality. After dinner his Highness will attend a horse parade! previous to opening the Show,and be will leave for Alexandria at 4 p.m. An attendance of between fifty and sixty thousand persons is expected. Order will be maintained by a force Tot 250 soldiers in addition to the police, anf Mansfield Pasba will be in direct supervision, Two banquets will be given by the Municipality of Tantah, to one of which one hundred Earopeana have been invited, and the other will be a wallimeh, of which 300 native notabilities will partaka. Subscriptions have been collected for the show and include £300 from the Municipality and £350 from individual persons. Prince Omar Pasba Toussoun will be the guest of the Moudir.
The Earl of Cromer will sail for Egypt on the 12th instant. (Reuter)

div.head:
SURVEY DEPARTMENT.
IMPORTANT APPOINTMENT.
div.p: The Egyptian Government has appointed Major Henri Gustave Joly de Lotbinière, D.S.O., R.E., to an important position in the Survey Department under Captain H. G. Lyons. He belongs to a Huguenot Canadian family, and is a distinguished member of the Royal Engineers. He was born on the 10th March, 1868, and is the son of thg Hon. Sir Henry Gustave Joly de Lotbinière, K.C.M.G., V.C., (Canada). D. C. L., (France) L.L.D., Lieutenant Governor of British Colombia. He is the great-grandson of the last Marqois de Lotbinière and his father adopted his present Burname under a provincial statute in 1888. His mother is the daughter of Hammond Gowon, of Qeteo. The Major married in 1902 Mildred Louis, daughter of C.E. Grenfell, and he is thus & relation of the former Sirdar. He entered the army in 1888, Captain. 1889. and Major, 19 0. He served in the North West frontier of India in 1897 98 (medal with three. clasps). South Africa, 1899 1902 (despatches twice brevet of Major, Queen's and King's medals 5 clasps, D.S.O.)

div.head:
NATIONAL UNIVERSITY SCHEME.
THE GIFTS OF THE WEALTHY.
div.p: A munificent donation of L.E. 10,000 and 100 feddans of land has been made by Ahmed Bey Cherif, a notable of Kafr-Zayat, for the furtherance of the scheme of establishing a National University.

Mohamed Effendi Badir, of Ramleb, Mahmoud Boy el Shiebin, of Maballa el Kebir, Khalil Bey Faid, ex-aub modir of Assouan, Sheikh Ibrahim Daalias, of Sharkieh, Said Bey Zaglool and Kasseim Bey Amin, councilors of the native Court of Appeal, have each subscribed LE 100. O.mau Bey Islam, of Beni Souef, has enggested through the medium of "Al. Mosyad” that fifty subscriptions of L.E. 2,000 would furnish the required gum, and he has offered that amount himself.
The total subscriptions now amount to L.B. 14,700.

div.head:
THE SINAI PENINSULA
THE BEDOUIN RAIDERS
div.p: The latest London papers to band confirm the news of the withdrawal of the Turkish garrison of Kusaima contained in our special service telogram of the 1st inst. We hear that Kusaima is well supplied with water, three springs, each of which gives birth to a small stream, affording a constant Supply to the Bedouins of the district. An excellent well was found at El Adjs by the frontier commi-sion in the neighbourhood of the ruins of an ancient castle constructed by the Crusaders to check Saracen raide. Several crosses were out in the walls of a rained chapel and fragments of a Greek inscription, dating perhaps from Byzantine timer, in which the word "eteleatėsan" (they) 'died' could be deciphered.

The Bedouin raiders mentioned in our last issue are described as well armed and equipped. They had martinis, swords, daggers, and pistols, and every man was accompanied by a spare camel. Their dress and appearance was very different from that of most of the Bedouins on the Egyptian side of the frontier, and while the latter are in general poorly armed and equipped, the raiding party which Mr. Keeling encountered constituted a formidable fighting force of about 110 men. It appears to have been composed of contingents from the Ibn Jozi, Turkish Barakat, and another tribe, and its object was the Hiwawat olan with which the Arabs on the Ottoman side of the frontier have a feud.

div.head:
SPLENDID HOTELS OF EGYPT CO.
NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL.
div.p: The New Khedivial Hotel at Alexandria has been undergoing a complete transformation during the summer months. and in a very short space of time this magnificent hotel will be completely finished. During the past year seventy-one new bedrooms, four bathrooms and other offices have been added and there are now one hundred and forty bedrooms. The new electric lift, by Stigler of Milan, goss, up to the top stories, and on the terrace of the third floor a large steam laundry has been set up. One of the greatest improvements has been the entire alteration of the kitchen arrangement. Hitherto the service was most awkward owing to the kitchen being situated ten minutes from the dining rooms. Now the old bar has been done away with, and part of it has been converted into an entrance to the kitchen which is now only two minutes from the restaurant. The remaining portion of the old bar has been turned into a couriers' dining room and the new bar has been placed on the original site of the hotel bar on the side facing the Zizinia Theatre. The new bed. rooms have been furnished throughout by Maple and are got op most artistically. All the wallpapers have been chosen with the greatest care and no paint has been spared to adorn each room with all the resourcer of European civilisation. On the 15th inst. the last workman will leave the hotel and the final touches are now being given to the grillroom, which is to take the place of the old terrace. The services of a first-class English cook have been engaged for the grill room, which will be used especially for gappers. A barman from the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel at New York is arriving next week for the American bar. All the rooms of the hotel have been retained beforehand and every room will be engaged by the end of October. Seventy rooms are already taken for the 20 h inst. Mr. Frank Reinsperger, the new manager, who was for ten years at Shepheard's Hotel, has. been most energetic in his endeavours to have all the many improvements effected in the shortest possible time and he has been thoroughly successful in transforming the hotel so as to meet all the demands of its large clientèle.

div.head: STEAMERS MOVEMENTS.
div.p: The Papayanni liner Sardinia left Malta last evening, and is expected to arrive at this port on Tuesday next.
The Papayanni liner Assiout sailed from Liverpool yesterday.
The Norddeutscher Lloyd S.S. Hohenzollern left Naples yesterday, and is due at Alexandria at 9 a.m. on Monday.
The Khedivial express mail steamship Osmanieh will leave Alexandria at 4 p.m. on Wednesday for Piræus, Smyrna, Mitylene, and Constantinople.
The Cunard S.S. Pavia is due here on Monday, and will immediately begin loading cargo for Liverpool and America.

div.p: The Commercial and Financial Supplement of the "Egyptian Gazette" is published at midday every Saturday in time for the Austrian Lloyd's mail. The supplement contains exhaustive and important reviews of the cotton, cotton seed, and stock and share markets, with all the latest statistics up to the evening of the preceding day, complete tabular forms of the various market fluctuations, and the copies of the official telegrams of the Liverpool Cotton Association, etc., etc. Subscription for one year P.T. 100 (inclusive of postage in Egypt for abroad the postage is P.T. 10 extra). div.head:
THE LOST CITY OF MARIOUT.
EXCAVATION OF SAINT MENAS.
div.p: The recent wonderful discovery of the long lost city of Saint Monas in the wilds of the Mariont desert has aroused great interest throughout enlightened Barope, for although it was known that this ancient city did exist, and that its site was only a few miles from Alexandria, all attempts to discover the whereabouts had been fruitless. Before the Christian Era the city had been a central point for the trade and caravan routes from Alexandria to Cyrene and the Oasig of Ammon and from central Egypt to the North West, but it is chiefly known to fame for the extraordinary sanctity, which it subsequently obtained owing to the execution of Mena, an officer in the army, son of & Governor of a province of Afrioa, who suffered martyrdom under Diocletian. His body was buried there and a Church was built to mark the spot. At the end of the fourth century a magnificent basilica was erected in the reign of Arcading and became a great resting place for pilgrims and travellers on their way from Alexandria to Nitria. A description is extant by an Arab geographer, who describes the Church of St. Mona as still standing, apparently, in an uninjured condition.

The date at which this description should be placed is probably between the early part of the eleventh and the early part of the fourteenth century, i.e. subsequent to the great destruction of churches in Egypt by the Caliph Hakim, when thirty thousand churches are said to have been ruined in Syria and Egypt. Since that date the old city has utterly disappeared from history and BirMassie Blomfield in the Bulletin of the Alexandria Arobæɔlogical Society for 1904 stated that it is believed that the site was known to the Bedouins, and he added :

"It seems to me that the identification of this site with the assistance of the Coast Guard authorities would be a suitable one on which to expend some portion of the funds of the Arcbæological Society.” But the honour of the discovery of this long-lost city belongs to two German Archæologists, the Rev. O. M. Kaufmann and Mr. J.C.E. Falls who alighted on the rains on Jane 7, 1905. They have now compiled an account of their excavations during their first campaign, from November, 1905, to Jane, 1906. The work has just been published at Cairo, and is on sale at Diemer's Library (78. 6d.). It is well printed and illustrated with 54 autotypes, which give the reader an excellent idea of the comprehensive character of the work of excavation and of the many and various artistic finds that have been the outcome of these excavations. This book, which is dedicated by the authors to Schiess Pasbe, gives a most interesting account of the discovery of one of the greatest arobæological mysteries in Egypt, and should be read by all who take an intelligent interest in the ancient history of this country. The record of their work is carried on until last Jone. Since then the Rev. O. M. Kaofmann and Mr. Falls have excavated the buildings connected with the basilica of Arcadias, the principal baptistry of the city, a part of the north cemetery with its basilica, and a small track of the recently discovered south cemetery. Work is now being carried on in the ancient Koinobion. In Menas City all the principal buildings and churches are several metres underground and the work is of greatly difficulty. Some fifty cisterne have been discovered, and some of these have been excavated. For centuries no water has been obtainable at Karm Aba Mina, except daring the winter months, and the water has to be supplied by a camel caravan from a village four miles away.

div.head: THE MONEY FAMINE.
div.p: Within the next nine days £1,700,000 are expected to arrive at Alexandria from London, and this with the payment of the dividend on the Privileged Debt on the 15th inst. will considerably alleviate the stringency.

div.head: CORPORATION OF WESTERN EGYPT.
div.p: Very satisfactory samples of Abbasi Afifi and Yanovitz cotton grown on the lands watere dby the new bored holes at Khargeh have been received by the Corporation of Western Egypt. The Ashmouni cotton was planted rather late, and Is not yet ready for picking. The lands uponw hich most of the crop referred to was grown had never been cultivated or watered before. Very good samples of the wheat and barley of the winter crop are also to hand.

div.head: LAND BANK OF EGYPT.
div.p: It will be remembered that at the extraordinary general meeting of the shareholders of the Land Bank of Egypt, which was held in Alexandria on September 8, the creation of a further £2,500,000 of debentures was authorised, making the total authorised £5,000,000. The amount at present issued is £1,000,000 in 50,000 three and-a-half per cent. bonds of 500f (£20), and a further issue of 90,000 four per cent. bounds of 500f. each will shortly be made. The full details of this issue will be found in the financial portion of to-day's issue.

div.head:
THE "TIMES" ARTICLE.
"AL MINBAR'S" REPLY.
div.p: To the EDITOR OF THE "Earprian Gazette."
Dear Sir, In "The Times” of the 18th ult. a letter appeared under the heading, "The Situation in Egypt'' signed by "Phylax” which contained the following passage :--

"A new journal belonging to the National party has made its appearance ander the name of the "Minbar," or "Palpit," whose opening statement that although holding bigh its duties to its country, Egypt, it holds still higher its doties to its religion, Islam, sounds Ja premonitory note of its probable fatore tone-a dangerous one. It is now engaged in attacking Lord Cromer, and discusses his probable recall with a wealth of inventive | faculty fally qualifying the journal even tbus early to proudly claim equality on the score of veracity with the 'Lewa' itself."

As the statements of "Phylax” are erroneous, and not only calculated to create a false impression amongst those of your com| patriots who are unacquainted with arabio, but aleo to do harm to the Cango we desire to serve, might I crave the hospitality of your columns in order to place matters in their true light?

"Al Minbar” was started a fow months ago by Mohamed Massoud Effendi and myself, with results which are already gratifying to us both-its sole proprietors. The policy of our paper, from its inception, has been one of complete independence. We are under no bond or obligation to anyone, nor has any Power or Party the right to dictate to us the politioaľ views which they seek to propagate. Whilst laying no claim to infallibility, our purpose is to uphold the cause of justice, liberty and equality, to expose abuses and to lead our countrymen along the path of progress and enlightenment. In this sense, and in this sense alone, we are Nationaliste. We are likewise, and for similar reasons, Pan-Islamists.

Pan-Islamism we regard as a potent social force linking together and rallying onder one standard of cooperation the various communities of Mohamedans scattered throughout the world, so that by cooperation they may unitedly assert their rightful claims amongst the nations of whom they are subjects. I know it has been alleged that therein lurks a danger to Christendom. I grant that in the hands of unscrupulous and interested sectaries such may be the case. Bot "Al Minbar" never has, and so long as it remains ander its present management, never will support a selfish war of creeds or races.

My studies in English history and politics would have availed me little had I not imbibed therefrom something of the Englishman's sense of order. Our paper, "The Tribune," as its name implies, is intended to be the organ of the people, to voice their legitimate aspirations and to ventilate their real grievances ; and I should like to know what fair-minded Englishman would blame as for that or find danger in espousing each a noble cause. Criticism, be it. ever so honest, when ad verse is rarely relished. by those against whom it is directed. But criticism is as the breath of its nostrils to the pablio Press, and provided that personalities are not indulged in and bias excluded, nothing could be more salutary. Egypt especially needs it, for the Press in this country is the solo channel whereby pablic opinion can find expression and be justly gauged. Let me, finally, assure yoo, Sir, and those of your readers who deign to peruse these lines that we have no axe to grind, no personal ambition to gratify, save that of rendering disinterested service to the Egyptian nation by raising the | tone of the vernacular journalism.
Thanking you by anticipation for the publication of this letter in your valuable colomp. - I am, Sir,
Your faithfully.

div.head: THE BRINDISI MAIL.
div.p: TO THE EDITOR OF THE "EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.”

Sir, — You will have 'the British. Colony with you if you demand a fall, searching and independent inquiry into the causes of the non arrival of the "Isis" on Wednesday morning. There are rumours afloat, pamely, that the ship was known to be in an unseaworthy condition by reason of a partial disablement of her machinery before she left port, and it is dow alleged that she has put into Zante with | a broken shaft. Of course the company will be prepared with an exculpatory explanation, for that is the way with companies as with governments whenever they are called to 40count. But that will not satisfy the publio. What they went, and you should insist upon their having, is an independent official in. vestigation. To pat a company upon its defence and to rest satisfied with whatever excuse it may, choose to offer is like calling upon the accused to sit in judgment upon him. self. In the interests of public safety, in which I include both passengers and crew, the whole impartial truth, as it can alone be elicited by , & commission of experts, should be made known, so that the blame, if blame there be, should rest upon the proper shoulders and due precautions taken, should such be possible, against the recurrence of similar accidents. But the breakdown of the "Isia” and its alleged navigation in spite of what had happened opens up wider issues. What is the exact nature of the arrangements made between

Postal ships and the Postal authorities regard delivery of mile ? To, be explicit, are the subsided mail steamship companies under contract to perform voyages within a certain limit of time, and they liable to penalties in every instance failure from whatever cause ? If such the case, contracts of the description, I maint ought to be declared null and void on ground of public policy, aye, for the sak humanity. Ships can be ignored, sometime they are over ignored, at, least Mr. Ch berlain used to tell os i the old days. If ship goes down the lost is merely a monete one. But in the event of loss of life, em though each lives may be insured, can it said that any monetary indemnity can regarded as an adequate solution ? If any time clause exists such as I have suggested it ought to be cancelled forthwith by all civilized governments for this alternative of endangering that most precious and irreparable of all possessions -dear human life-or committing a breach of contract entailing upon a mais steamship Co. Heavy penalties in a temptation which a Captain may not be always able to resist and it is certainly one which should never be placed in his way.

In the above observations I have said nothing about the inconvenience which a delay of mails occasions to the business community of Egypt,let alone all the other farther east. This though important, is a consideration of minor moment to those I have argued. At the same time might it not be possible for a Co. like the P. & O. to have two ships ready to carry the mails from Brindisi to Port Said and vice versa so as thus to minimise the chances of delay !
Yours truly,

div.head: DEATH OF COLONEL BLUNDELL.
div.p: Colonel Henry Blundell Hollinshead-Blundell, formerly member of parliament for the Ince Division of Lancashire, died yesterday week at his London residence, Stratton-street, Picondilly, aged seventy-five years. The oldest son of the late Mr. R. B. Blundell-Hollinshead. Blundell, of Deysbrook, he was born in 1881, and was educated at Eton and at Christ Charoh, Oxford, graduating in 1854. Ho entered the Army as a second lieutenant in the Rifle Brigade in 1855, and was promoted lieutenant in the same year, and served in the Crimean Campaign after the fall of Sebastopol. He received the brevet of colonel in April, 1881, and in 1884-85 served with the Nile Expedition on the Staff as inspecting officer of the lines of communication, and afterwards as commandant at Dongola, being mentioned in despatches, and receiving for his services the medal with clasp and the Khedive's star. He was nominated a C.B. in June, 1887, and retired in January, 1889.

The "Temps" has published a confidential report from the Russian Minister of Finance to M. Stolypin declaring that the Treasury shows a deficit amounting to 155,000,000 roubles. A foreign loan is unlikely, but he recommends the issue of a new series of rentes. It is imperative that a restriction should be placed on the expenditure. (Reuter)

An official statement has been issued controverting the pessimistic view taken by the "Temps." It says that the object of M. Kokovtzeff's letter was merely to point out the necessity for avoiding unauthorized expenditure. There was every ground for viewing the financial situation favourably. The statement is regarded as practically a confirmation of the "Temps" report. (R.)
The Tsar has arrived at Peterhof. (Reuter)

div.head: THE NEW CUNARDER.
div.p: The builders of the Mauretania, the newest liner of the Cunard Steamship Company, just floated, supply some interesting particulars regarding this monster vessel.

Grey's Monument in Newcastle is 133ft. high. The captain's bridge on the liner from the keel is the same height, the fappels standing about half that height above the bridge. Twenty trains, each of twenty large trucks would be required to carry the coal necessary for a voyage to New York and back, and the coal consumed on such a voyage would be efficient to keep fires going in 3,000 workmen's houses for a year. About 250 firemon and trimmers will be necessary to deal with the coal.

If the funnels were placed one above another they would make a column 430 ft. high, while it the boilers were placed one above another they would form a column 547ft. high. Two hundred and fifty persons could lunch in one of the funnels, each person being seatel comfortably at the table. Not counting the pipes for steam and water connections, there will be about 1/4 miles of brass and steel tubes fitted to boilers, conden. bers, eto. In the engine-room there will be nearly 600 tons of rotary machinery.

In the turbines there will be three-quarters of a million of blades, which, if placed end to ond, would measure 110 milen. Two electric trains could pass each other side by side in the condenser exhaust branch. The average length of the steam and feed pipes in the machinery rooms will be about a mile and a quarter. Some of the larger castings weigh about 38 tons each. The weight of the ingots from which the large drums were forged was 120 tons each. There will be 200 miles of electric cables in the hip. The electric generating station of the ship is larger than that which supplies Paisley, a town of 87,000.

div.head: THE REBELS OF THE YEMEN
div.p: In that masterpiece of English literature "The Life of Mahomet" by Washington Irving, the man who may be aptly described in his own words as "For all he did he had a reason, for all he said a word in Beason, and over ready was to quote authorities for what he wrote" much may be learned of the early history of the present inhabitants of Arabia. Moch information, as the author acknowledge was drawn from Gagnier's translation of the Arabian historian Abu'feda, preserved in the Jesuits' convent of St. Isidor at Madrid.
The population of the Peninsula olaim, direct descent from Jootar, a great grandson of Shem, immortal for all time as one of tho-8 who shared the refuge of the Ark.

The kingdom of Yemen was founded by Yareb, one of his sons. A brother Jorham founded the kingdom of the Hedjaz. It was into the latter family that Ishmael married. From the twelve sons of the marriage the present prolific race really took their origio. ; In addition to carrying on the tradition or being wildmen like their progenitor "his hand against every man, and every man's hand against him," they also retain to a certain extent some of the characteristics of their Jewish ancestor pot only in their features, but also in their ability to accumulate flocks and herds.
Gradually there grew up a distinction between those wh» "beld towns and castles" and those who "dwelt in tents.”

Of the former we are told that they occupied the fertile wadies or valleys, scattered here and there among the mountains, where these towns and castles were surrounded by vineyards and orchards, groves of palm trees, fields of grain, and well stocked pastures. They were settled in their habits, devoting themselves to the cultivation or the soil and the breeding of cattle.

Others gave themselves up to commerce, having ports and cities along the Red Sea ; the southern shores of the Peninsula and the Gulf of Persia, and carrying on foreign trade! by means of ships and caravans.

Such especially were the people of Yemen. or Arabia the Hs, py, that land of spices, perfumes and frankincense ; the Sibaas of the poets, the Sheba of the Sacred Scriptures. Engaged as they were in the pursuits of peace, the inhabitants lost mooh of the original characteristics of the Arab, who, through the necessity of always having to defend his flocks and herds was familiar with arms almost from infancy,
Yemen, owing to its wealth and accessibility, became the happy hunting ground for the adventurous invader who always carried on war on the principle of "The spoils to the conqueror.”

Since those days the various tribes have never been united except that they embraced the faith as expounded by Mahomet. Without any real say in the government of their countries they have gradually seen the trade of the old days depart from their shores. The opening of the Suez Canal following after the discovery of the Cape ronto to India meant to them the loss of a great source of livelihood in the passage of the numerous caravans through their territory.
At one time Mocha coffee was a commodity which meant much to the people of the Yemen.

Since the opening out of other sources of obtaining coffee, more especially the development of the West Indian Trade, even the taste for Mocha coffee has been lost. It is A well-known fact that people can acquire a taste and liking for an article really inferior to that which they may have at one time been accustomed. To-day most people who were offered pore Mocha coffee would not tha k you for it, but still there is some demand for the article although we fear the supply is precarious, and what is often drunk as pare Moobs bas seldom been grown in Arabia. Of late years the hold of the most recent conquerors, the Turks, has gradually been relaxed in the Yemen. Powersa obiefs have been silently organizing until wa b»ve witnebi ed not only the commence. ment of a rebellion, but also what look almost like a successful attempt to throw off the Turkish yoke.

The garrison drawn from the seventh army corps at Sanaa, the capital, a town of 75,000 inhabitants, held out against odds and under difficulties besides which the troubles and hardships of the defenders of Ladysmith sink into insignificance. Suoh was the stubborn resiste noe of the Tark that, long before the arrival of Faizi Pasba, hastily sent out with reinforcements ill-equipped and devoid of an organized transport as the term is known to modern adjutants general, cannibalism was rife. Indeed the first relief column to arrive considerably added to the distress, as before entering Sanas much of their transpor had been captured by the rebels. When the remnant of the garrison ultimately reached the coast and took abip at Hodoida, they presented a spectacle reminiscent of the rigours, of the sieges of ancient times; haggard, gaunt human skeletons, smitten with sourvy, their bodies
covered with sores, they could hardly crawl abroad the ship.

In spite of statements to the contrary, it is now known that over a hundred of these poor remnants of humanity died either at or before reaching Saez. In such a state of direful desolation was the ship that she went into voluntary quarantine, and quite a small graveyard marks the place where her freight was camped.

Small wonder that other transports coming from Syria and other countries with troops uninterested in a war in which others were attempting to rid them of a tyranny which they themselves would gladly be free from, in some cases landed almost in a state of mutiny. How grəst a soldier Faizi Pasha is can only be recognised when one remembers that although his troops are second to none in courage, he has not been able either to pay, fead, or clothe them with any regularity.

Acting in a difficult country often far from his base Without being able to keep up lines of communication it is small wonder that he and his advisers have seen the inutility of 50,000 troo: a holding a country, under the present conditions, against three times their number of resolute men imbued with patriotism and zeal and mad with the fruits of victory. Hon over, evidently taking a leaf out of Kitchener’s book, Turkey has decided to build a line from Hodeida direct to Sanaa, a distance of 200 kilometres.

At first this line built for strategic purposes is eventually to be used to develope the internal resources of the country. The laying of a line from Aden to Athela, 28 often suggested, would also direct into British channels of trade some of these resour088.

The absurd stories that England had intentions of backing ep the rebels and assisting by allowing "gun running” to establish an autonomy in the Yemen and so open out an alternative route for her Mohamedan subjects to reach Mecca in the pilgrimage need only to be mentioned to be shown to be a concoction of that section of the Continental native press ever ready to probe for ulterior motives and designs.

A direct pronouncement on the part of England that she had no designs on the territory of the Hedjaz, in which rest the sacred cities, and that on the contrary that not only will she hold these agored places inviolate, but will see that others also respect them would go far to remove any distrust which may yet remain as to her intentions.

The ultimate upshot of the Yemen rebellion, although it has as yet attracted little attention will be looked forward to with considerable interest by those who recognise that as the Extreme Western and Eastern portions of the globe become exhausted as the hunting grounds for the nations eager to expand their trade and infinence more and more attention will return to the spheres where in olden time we are told that civilization first had its origin.

div.head: CAPE TO CAIRO CINEMOTOGRAPHED.
div.p: Eight years ago, almost to the day, a Cape Town contemporary announced with much blowing of trumpets the arrival in the Colony from London of a gentleman who was equipped with the latest style of cinematograph, with the intention of taking some photographs of the different parts of South Africa. "He intende," stated the paper from which we quote, 'manipulating the machine from a tramcar, and thus be enabled to produce in England and elsewhere the scenery from Cape Town to Wynberg, and in the same manner some of the best views to be met with along the line from Cape Town to Johannesburg. He has arranged with the railway authorities to have a special saloon car attached to an up-country train, and in order not to miss any of the best scene, which will probably be passed through during the night, will retaro along the same route."

History is curiously silent as to the sequel. Whether the gentleman referred to succeeded | in his enterprise deponent knoweth not, but| certain it is that, if he dil, his efforts and hardly be said to have set the Thames on fire. Let us hope that Mr. Charles Urban - a name familiar in men's months as household words where animated photography is concerned will be more successful. Ever on the lookout for something new, he has hit upon the happy idea of "doing" the Dark Continent from Cape Town to Cairo by means of the "Urbanora,” and is now busily perfooting Archeme for sending outdoor expeditions to various parts of Africa, commencing simulta. neously at Cape Town and at Cairo. It is a splendid notion, and one which, we feel gore, would have commended itself to the great heart of the late Mr. Rhodes, who doubtless would have been the first to perceive in it a most effective means of advertising Africa and its vast resources, with a view to stimulating an early and large influx of population from the United Kingdom.

"The object of the undertaking,” said Mr. Urban, in the course of conversation with a representative of the "African World," is to secure & most comprehensive series of life motion pictures of the rezonroeg and indag. tries already in operation in the territories en route, also general views of the character of the country. Special attention will be directed to accurately and advantageously dopict, in detail, the agricultural, mining, stock-raising, rail-roading, and other transport facilities and their development in British South Africa, Uganda, Congo States, and the country between the Victoria Falls and Fa: aboda, algo thronghont Egypt to Cairo. A living reproduction of these scenes would be of exceeding interest to investors, intending emigrante, touriste, sportsmen, and others, and of immense benefit to all Governments, companies, railways, hotels, and individuals concerned in the commercial expansion of Africa.

"No other means devised can 80 forcibly or convincingly pat Africa, or the possibilities of its developments, before the investing public of all countries 48 Urbanorà. This we have demonstrated by our undertakings on similar lines in depicting Canada, South America, Borneo, Australia, Switzerland, etc., with which pictures the public has been fomil. iarised daring the past three years, much to the benefit of those countries. The leaders of this expedition are picked men of experience, discretion, and resource, export photographers and journalists, and are equal to the work of sach & large undertaking. Upon the termination of the expedition the results will be exhibited by 'Urbalora' at the Alhambra Theatre, London, as well as publicly shown in some eight hundred to a thousand theatres and places of entertainment throughout England, Continental Europe and America, besides other countries. An explanatory lecture tour by the leaders of the expedition upon their return will likewise be undertaken throughout Great Britain. In this way it is expected to keep the different sections of the African series exhibited consecutively before the public during the course of one year and after.

"Arrangements," went on Mr. Urban, "have been made with leading journals for descriptive illustrated articles, contributed by the leaders of the party, to appear during the progress of the exhibition and lecture tour, lo order to facilitate the vast undertaking, we have decided to start four separate expeditions into different sections of Africa, within a few months of each other. This will enable us to reach the various countries during the most favourable climatic conditions (which is highly essential to our purposes), instead of one expedition undertak. | ing the entire work from the Cape to Cairo."

Naturally, an undertaking of the kind would involve the expenditure of a very large sum of money, and we were scarcely surpristal: to hear that the Charles Urban Trading Company, Limited, invite the financial - operation of the principal South African companies for the southern section of the work and we make no doubt that when once the scheme is thoroughly understood by the chiefly concerned the necessary assistance will speedily be forthcoming. Already a good start has been made. Questioned on the subject by our representative, Mr. Charles Urban replied: "We are willing to contribute one half of the expenses incurred on the trip, provided the other half of the cost is subscribed by the various companies and firms who would benefited by the carrying out of our project. We are only asking co-operation from a few the principal South African companies, want the proper assistance and facilities our men in order that they may secure best results.” "You have 'worked' Canada and Australia on similar lines already, have you not, Mr. Urban ?' 'Yes, and our success in those undertakings was due to the fact it we know how to produce a picture series who is novel, attractive, entertaining and instinctive, containing advertising value without reflecting in the least from the general intent of the subject depicted. I am proud to say that we have never yet failed to produce the most satisfactory results of the work undertaken."

EMISSION DE 90,000. OBLIGATIONS HYPOPHRCAIRES 4% de Fcs, 500 AU PORTEUR
INTERET ANNUEL : 20 Francs (net
d'impôts présents et futurs). Payables par coupons semestriels les 1er Janvier
et ler Juillet de chaque année.
La LAND BANK OF EGYPT prend à sa charge les impôts français présents et futurs et les impôts qui pourraient être établis en Egypte.
Les titres seront remboursables à 500 francs par voie de tirages annuels au plus tard en 75 ans.
Les tirages auront lieu le ler Juin de chaque année et le remboursement des titres amortis s'effectuera le ler Juillet suivant.
Le premier tirage aura lieu le ler Juin 1907.
L'intérêt attaché aux titres cessera à partir du jour fixé pour le remboursement.
Les coupons échus et les titres sortis au tirage seront payables à Paris en monnaie française, ainsi qu'en Egypte, à Londres, Bruxelles, Bâle, Genève et Amsterdam, au cours du change à vue sur Paris.
Les coupons échus et le capital des titres amortis seront périmés dans un délai de 30 ans,

i 175 -— du 16 au 20 Novembre, on supportant sur ce dernier versement un intérêt de 4 % compter du 16 Octobre.

div.head: Cotons
div.p: Ce que nous prê bions depuis une éternité s'est eofin réalisé : La hanage de l'américain est eurvende et il a soffi de la cor firmation des quelqres dégâts dont ont parlé les dépêches de la semaine dernière pour la provoquer. Ce n'est pas par simple esprit de vanité que nous avons commencé avec ce préambule, mais notre but est de constater qu'à la suite de oe qui est arrivé pendant la huitaine, presque tous nog lecteurs ont fini par reconnaitre que nous avions yo jaste dans tout ce que nous avons écrit depois que'que temps au gdjet de la situation cotonpière. Ce n'est pas une mince satisfaction pour nous et cela efface l'omerto me ressentie parfois à la baite de critiques injustes goi nous ont été adreszees 'qoand notre opinion déplaisait à l'op ou à l'autre. Ceci dit, paseoDB à la revne da marobé.

Samedi eyant été jour férié, la reprise des aff, ires n'a eg lien que londi et comme début 2008 avong on à enregistrer pour la dite matinée une avance dette de 11/32. Pour le lendemain, c'est une nouvelle hajsko de 7/82 qui est venue s'rjonter, la clôture syant eu Teu à 17 1/16, après que, comme maximum dous avions pratiqué le cours de 17 13/32. Mercredi, le Novembre ent monté à 17 15/32. mais comme finale il s'est inscrit à 16 15/16.

La haqrae dans les deux journées avait été faite par les nouvelles d'Amérique, tandis que la réaction n'a été que le résultat des atteques da parti de la baisse qui a réusei à entraver la marche en avant aveo sea continnelles ventes. Dans tous les cao, au fond, il y avait une cer: taine fermeté et la preave on est qu'hier, et malgré la baisse inattendne d'une cinquan. taine de points dans la cote de New York, c'est à peine si le copra de Novembre était tombé pour un moment à 16 13/16 pour finir à 16 29/32.

Quant à la séance de ce jour, elle a 6'6 fayo risée par la reprise de New York, et qooigne le maximam de 17 3/16 n'ait pa être maintena, la semaine s'est terminéa ep baq8se, quand même, 20 la veille à la cote de 17 1/32.

Cela nous fait 17/32 de gagné pour la 40maine, mais ce qui est encora miel x, c'est le revirement que l'on remarque dans la tends nce: Le miché est frar chement pour la hausse et Bi l'Amérique son é'iore encore, nous pourrions bien avoir un caut assez important dans les prix. Aux coors actuele, il y rapprochement sensible entre américain et égyptien, et oe dernier ne pent dore que gagner dans la faveur de la consommation ; do rerte, la filature an. glaine d'a pas trop regardé à la haneke et al encore fait quelqyos achats à livrer sor notre burché pendant la semaine qui vient de fidir.

Constatons encore que le déport qui existait por janvier diminte cheque jour davantage et que treg probablement, d'ioi peu de temps, nous verrons t30s les mois é oigr és s'ét: blir en report, comme cela e:t invariable ment Sabi nde sor notre marché.

Sans rovenir à la situation gé, é ale de l'ar, il est naturellement difficile, dans l'exci. ation du moment, do' se faire une opinion ant à l'avenir ; mais ce que l'on peut dire, est qu'en Amérique le mouvement semble avoir une durée assez longué encore. so effet, on parle d'un corner sor octobre et yowme le découvert est colossal et que la

main d'œuvre pour faire la cueillette n'abonde pas, one pareille combinaison rentre dans le domaine du possible. Si dopo ce que l'on dit Be vérifie, il va de soi que le coton égyptien ne pourra qu'en profiter.

Le resserrement d'argent qui a contribué quelque peu à talmer l'ardeur de pos haussiers pereiste topjonte, mais les jours de cette petite crise sont comptés. Il y a beaucoup d'or en route et d'ici an 15 courant toute trace de la pénurie actuelle aura dispara. ,

On dit que la hausse de l'Améridain profite largement à l'Egypte; ce n'est pas une mauvaise nouvelle qoe nous donnons Ja, et tout ce que nous sophaitons c'est que le fait soit vrai, oar de cette sorte, ontre le béné. fice indirect que le pays retire de l'améliora. tion dont l'égyptien profite par ricochet, il y anrait de ce chef teancoup d'argent qui rentrerait dans les poches de dos spéculateurs.

Les avis de la récolte sont moins bons qu'ils ne l'étaient, il y a quelque temps, mais comme nos lecteurs le verront par le Résumé de Septembre de la Produce Association que nous reprodaisons plos loin, la récolte est considérée quand même bien supérienre à celle de l'année passée. A remarquer toutefois qu'il y a eu des dégâts et que telle qu'elle est représer téa adjourd'hui, elle ne peut plus être cette record crop dont parle an des rapports da Ministère des Travaux Pahlids.

On a irangoré ces joprs-ci les affaires sur ni vembre 1907 en commerçant par le coura de 15 11/16, ponr tomber engaite à 15 5/8. Le déport pour la récolte 1907 8 est assez seneible pour faire croire que très probablement la prochaine campagne, dans ces conditione, atti. rera l'attention de la filatare continentale qai avait déjà montré des dispositions à acheter pour novembre 1997 et janvier 1908. Dans tous les cas, cela fournit une base à l'exporttion et la spéculation qui est en train de o'smnser à acheter du mars 1906 et à vendre do novembre 1907 ferait bien de se modérer.

Le ma ché du disponible a été notif pendant la semair e, gro‘que ces donx derniers jours il y ait en un pen de ralentissemaut à cause de la sitnation financière de la place. Les prix ce. pendant, et malgré les fortes recettes, se main. tiennent assez bien, la baisse de la semaine D'Gant que de 1/2 tallari pour le Good Mit Affifi et de 3/3 poor les provenances Haute Eeyp'e. En son, we, la demande est bonne.

En fait d'exportat on, nous n'avons eu qoe | belles 13,100 ponr la remaire, contro 13,400 l'anr 60 dernière, mais il est à croire que la enaine prochaine offrira ample compensation, lle relevé des embarquements devant com prendre les srriérés de cette semaine restés en ensprno et q' i sont importante.

A ce p'opos, relevons qu'une ligne santée dans la composition de notre dernière revae a | facreé les cb ff es que nous avions donrés con me expéditions de l'apnée paseée. Il fan. drsit lire : Embai quements Octobre 60,000 balles, Novembre 130,000 billes, total pour les denx mois 19,000 balles,
Liverpool a éʻé agfez actif poor les égyptiens disponib'es, le ch ffre des ventes ayant ang. menté d'une leçid ma'quée ce jours derniers.
Pour ce qui est des prix, il y a de la bausze s it, 1/16 sur le spot coté à 9 9/16 poor le fully grod sair.
Quant aux futurs ils ont encore é'é mieux Tartagéx, la valeur do jour de l'Octobre étant de 9 1*/64 et celle du nov. de 8 58,64.
Les Américaina disponibles ont aussi été plas aninés, mais les affaires sont toujours entravées par la rareté du choix. En attendant,

sur la cote, il y a à relever une amélioration de 48 points pour le spot qoi vaat 6.14, tandis que les futurs s'inscrivent à 582, soit en bangge de 75 points, tant pour l'Ootobre Novembre, qge pour le Janvier Février.

P.S.—On nous informe à la dernière heure et pous donnons la nouvelle à titre de simple renseignement, que les cotone provenant des réceptions Anât ont été offerts au pair aveo le Novembre.-Nous nous attendions bien à cola pour le 22 Octobre, mais pas pour le 5 ! !

div.head: Graines de Coton
div.p: Les arrivages sont régnliers, mais pas encore epffi-ants poor los besoins actuels et tout naturellement cela contribue à la fermeté des prix.
Le cours du jour da disponible est de P.T. 63 1/2. | Les exportations sont fortes et promettent d'être satisfaisantes pour tout le mois.

Le marché des contrats est ferme et finit même en bangge à P.T. 63 3/4 ponr 'es 8 mois, mais la spéculation est toujours rése vée et les affaires en général eont limitées &px ( vérations des exportateurs qui achètent qoand ils ont à convrir quelques ventes, pour l'Europe. --

L'Angleterre se montre froide, mais au fond elle ne fait qu'acheter tout tranquillement. Elle ne se laisse pas ontrafoer sur les échéan. ces éloignées, car la spéculation månque chez nous pour lui forcer la main, mais pour les embarqaements rapprochés ella y met le prix. Les dernières cotộa de Hall sont de £6.11.3 première qoir zside Ootobre, £6 7/6 pour tout Octobre et £ 6 2/9 pour les 3 mois.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA GENERAL PRODUCE ASSOCIATION.
div.p: RESUME DES REPONSES REÇUES EN
SEPTEMBRE 1906

Pendant la première moitié de Septembre, les conditions atmosphériques ont été assez favorables aux cotonniers, mais pendant les derniers jours da mois, on a constaté de brosqae changements de température et des noita trop fraiches, accompagnées de quelques bouillards.

Ces circonstances n'ont pas été sana poire aux opltures; mai; leur action a été très irrégulière, et landis que plusieurs localités sont demeurées indemnes, d'autres ont souffert comme retard dans la cueillette et comme chute d'ane partie des noix de la dernière prodaotion.
Aussi, les dégâts sont diversement évalués ; toutefois, la généralité de nos correspondants sont toujours d'avis que la récolte, dans son ensemble, dépassera sensiblement celle de 1905.
Il n'a plas été question des vors, et l'eau abonde partout.
L'égrensge donre jusqa'à prérent deg ren. dements très irréguliers, et à peu près comme l'apnée passée.
Dans la Haute-Egypte, malgré la dimination de l'acréage, on espère obtenir une récolte égale à la précédente.

div.head: CHRONIQUE FINANCIERE
div.p: Alexandrie, le 5 Octobre.

Notre marobé des valeura, encouragé d'on côté par la haurie de co'ong - et de l'autre par les rachats da découvert, a débuté londi par ane reprise gérérale et importante. Dès le lendemain, malheureusement, après une ouverture pleine d'entrain et de promesses, le relèvement du teux d'escompte à 4 1/2 % est venu rappeler à la spéculation que la crise fidanoière révissait encore et a déterminé ane réaction ; dans l'ensemble la cote n'en est pas moins restée forme et en badsse partielle. Mercredi les affaires ont eu peu d'ampleur et 80 sont limi'éas an Comptoir sur lequel il a'est prodait on mouvement, ocoasionné SADB dogte par la prochaine assemblea générale et l'accaparemont des titres qui on est la conséIquenca babitaelle. Hier enfin la nouvelle s'est confirmée que l'argent faisait défaut sur place et que les banquog refasaient de faire des avances sur titres.

Cette disette de noméraire n'est pas nou. velle pour l'Egypte. On pant dire que chaque année à la même époque ello se produit aveo plas ou moins d'intensité ; mais d'ordinaire on (la sont venir; comme l'orage elle a des signes avantooareorg : les banques de montrent plus difficiles dans leurs avances sur titres, les reporta atteignent des prix élevés, les liquidations deviennent plus laborienses. Cette annéeJoi la crise est arrivée à l'improviste: du jour Jan lendemain les banques ont refusé d'avancer sor titres et que'q988-anee même ont renvoyé lo payement de leurs chèques à landi; alcone liquidation laboriouse n'a fait pressentir l'on. ragad. Co sorait, à ce que l'on prétend da moing, la hausse dn coton qui nous aurait valu oette surprise. Les établissements finan. oiers assurent, en effet, qu'ils avaient les dig. ponibilités ordinaires pour faire face aux de mandes d'argent de l'intér eor, mais cette hausgo da coton a tenté un si grand nombre d'agriculteurs à la fois qu'il y a eu vente en masse du coton, circonstance imprévue qui a occasioppé un drainage d'or formidable. La raison qoi avait amené la baurse des valeurs laodi dernier s'est dono trouvé être en même temps la cause indirecte de leur réaction par la pénurie mor étaire qu'elle a créée sur place.

Fait digne de remarque, cette éprenve qui adrait po jeter la paniqoe dans la corbeille des valeurs, n'a prodoit qu'ade réaction à peine sensible. Elle a démontré que la situation est absolument saine, les positions pon borobargées et les dé'entears actuels assez forts en général poor attendre des temps meilleurs.

Il faut avouer, cependant, que la gêne modé. taire D'est pas encore sur son déclin. Bien qu'en effet le taux d'escompte ait été bier rédoit de nouveau à 4 3/8 % nous voyons la proportico de la réserve aveo les engagements de la Barque en Angleterre diminuer de 42 7/8 % à 38 1/2 %. Le Consolidé Anglais s'avance de 86 1/2'à 86 5,8. Quantaox valears égyptiennes, elles font preuve d'an soatien de bon adgare à la boar e de Londres : la National Bank gagne Lême 1/4 de livre à 26 7/8.

A Paris, au contraire, il y a baisse en géné. ral. La Rente Frar çaisé, réactionne d 96.05. Ea hapuse, il n'y a que les actions de Sáez à 4460 et la Land Bank of Egypt à 220. Les autres valgors égyptiennes sont en réaction plus on moins sensible.

Comme résultat de la gomaine, on peat dire que comme ensemble nous restons au même point que vendredi pageé. Uo tiers des valeurs environ sont en hausse, on tiers en baisse et un tiera demearent stationnaires. Les fl otuations les plus remarquables sont : à la hausse, la Delta Light qui gagne 1/8, la dividende Tramways 6 frados, la Bébéra 1/8, les Markets 9 pence, mais surtout la Nile Land qui s'avance de 14 13/16 À 15 1/2 et la part de fondatoor Comptoir de 43 à 44 livree; à la baisse, la Daïa qui perd 1/8, la Deferre 1 Delta 1/8, et la Delta Land 1/8.

Il nous revient que le gouvernement égyptien n'est pa8 étranger au soutien actuel des coars: A peine la disette d'or loi at elle été condae qu'il s'est empressé anjvurd'hai même de mettre provisoirement à la disposition de
la National Bank certains fonda qoi d'ordi. alire ne sont pas destinés à cet objet. Il en résulte une détente por entanée qui couvre les besoins les plus pressants,

La souscription à l'émission des 90.000 obligations Land Bank of Egypt s'ouvre landi prochair, 8 octobre,et so clotoro le même joor. Ce sont des obligations bypothécaires de 500 frs. du type 4 %; le taux d'intérêt est de 20 francs ret de tout impôt et les coupons beme8triels sont payables le 1er janvier, et le ler juillet de chaque année. Los titres sont rom. bopraobles à 500 francs par voie de tirages annuels an plas tard on 75 ans. Le prix d'émission est de 4-5 franco, payables 100 francs en Bouscrivant et le solde à la répartition qoi agra lieu da 16 au 20 sourant. Pour l'Egypte, les souscriptions seront reçnes à la National Bank à Alexandrie et au Caire.

Mr. Mack, membro da Board fe Londreu de l'Egyptian Land and General Trust, se trouve ao Caire depuis une dizsine de jogrs. Il est, comme on le sait par le rapport de cette société, délégué en Egypte pour prendre en moins la direction de la société et procéder à la vente des terrains dont la cession serait jogée oppor. tane. Mr. Mack n'a pas reça de Londrea des communications spéciales au sujet de l'appel de fonds dont on avait parlé.

La Société Générale des Sucreries et de la Raffinerie d'Egypte rappelle à sea obligataires qu'au moment de l'échange des obligatione, les porteurs peuvent demander l'échange jur et simple oa l'échange aveo l'estampille dondant droit à un conpon annuel de 8 francs I pendant 3 ans, payable par semestre. L'option pour l'estampille prend fin le 31 décembre 1906. Pour les actions, une nouvelle sera remise en échange de trois anciennes. Les porteurs des titres, aotions et obligatione, peuvent dès maintenant les déposer contre op reça provisoire à échanger altérieurement contre les non veanx titres, au Caire, au siège de la société, à l'Anglo-Egyptian Bank ou à la National Bank et à Alexandrie à l'agence da Crédit Lyoppais.

A propos de la hausse récente de la Nile Land, nous oroyons intéressant de poblier les renseignements suivants : Le capital de oetto Boo é é est de LE. 300.c00, représenté par 60,000 actions de LE. 5. dont 45,000 avaient été allonées à M. Ch. Bacos, lors de la forma. tion de la compagnie, en échange de son appor: de 4.687 feddans de terrains dans la Haute-Bgypte et ailleurs, terrains gravés de LE 106,000 d'hypothèques et dettes dont la société a assumé la charge. Lea 45.000 actions de M. Bacos pourront, dès le 13 octobre conrant, aux termes des statuts, être négociées par lear propriétaire. Ce ne sora donc plus 15.000 Nile Land qu'il y aura sør le marché, mais bien 60.000. Il existe, on optre, 8000 parts de fondateurs dont le prix nominal est de 85 L.B.

Comme précédemment, nous avons la conviction que nos valenrs for cières sont appelées & profiter largement da prochain courant de hauese. L'événement nous a amplement donné raisop l'année passée et il n'y a pas de motif pour qu'il n'en soit pas de mêmo oette annéeci. Sans doute les titres qui ont déjà escompté presque tont l'avenir par une hausse proportionnelle doivent être écartés, mais il en est d'autres pour lesquels rien est escompté et dont la plag-value actuelle ne représente goère que le bénéfi:e des opérations réalisées. C'est à ceux oi qu'il convient de s'attecher.

div.head: JOINT SYSTEME BUHNE
div.p: pour manchons de tuyaux d'eau et de gaz.
Manehon dun tuyau de 300 mm de diametre rendu etanche par la laine de plomb Buhne et soumis à une pression de 20 Atmosphères.
Ju qu'à présent on assemblait les manchons de tuyaux on y introduisant tout d'abord une trosso de chanvr ut en coulant du plomb dans la partie rostéo vide, puis on mata le plomb coulé.

Nre nouveau système do raccord étanche se comporte tout autrement. Nous employons au lieu de plomb fondu laine du plomb brévotée en tres es de 1 m. de longueur et pesant 1, 1 ou 1 kilog. suivant les manchons, et prolons comme suit :

Aès avoir tout d'abord introduit ot comprimé la tresso do chanvro, on prend uno tresno do laine de plombu une partie soulement de la tresse, selon la force du joint, on l'enroule autour du tuyau et on la mato. fortem it dans le manchon ; on répète l'opération jusqu'à ce que le manchon soit complètement plein et bion mate. ar le fait que lo matage commence déjà au fond du manchon o. a. d. directement sur la trosso do chanvi la laine de plomb so transforme en uno masse homogène, au moyen de laquelle on réalise non seulent it une étanchéité parfaite, mais encore résistance beaucoup plus considérablo qu'auparavant.

Dessais de notre nouveau système de raccordement étanche ont été faits non seulement dans nos usines mais aussi en benucoup de villes qui en font l'étude à différents points de vue. Ainsi nous avons réalisé des janas de tuyaux de 300 et 450 mm de diametro d'après notre prooédé et soumis ces joints pendant des semair à une pression constante de 20 atmosphères Bä.8 gne lo raccord cédât. On réunit également bout bout 4 uyaux de 100 mm de diamètre d'après ngtre prooédé ; on plaça les deux extrémités sur doux supports de telle sorte que la partie intermédiaire no fat pas soutenue. On no constata ribsi aucune flexion. Par contre un ossiti analoguo aveo des joints en plomb fondu accusa uno floxion considérable...
Iainsi démontré qu'avec notre procéile on obtient un joint bien étanche el une résistance mécanique bien p grande qu'autrefois.
Nro nouveau procédé de raccordement étanche offre en outre l'immense avantage de permettre de travtr par tous log tomps et sans nécessiter la mise à seo des manchons.
Oro cos énormes avantages techniques, notro procédé présento vis--vis des anciens procédés encore d'autres.

Lopareil enconibrant pour le coulage du plomb est supprimé, d avec lui tout le combustible tel que bois et coke; perte de plomb à la coulée est évitée, on supprime de même le sable, la main d'euvre de moulage des tétes deimd hons et la main d'awure de conlage.
Dnotre procédé il no faut plus que dos matours.
Ionsuit que notre méthode rend le travail plus boonomique que l'ancien procédé, sans parler des avant is concernant l'hygiène.

div.head: NOTICE.
SUDAN GOVERNMENT.
DISPOSAL OF BUILDING SITES AT PORT SUDAN.
div.p: The Sudan Government will shortly dispose by Tender of about 400 Building Sites at Port Sudan.
The sites will be Leasehold held at Annual Rents on Building Lease for Eighty Years from 1st January, 1907. Rents will be payable only from date of acceptance of Tender.
The Lease will be Perpetually Renewable at Revised Rents fixed in default of Agreement by Arbitration at the end of each term of years.
In fixing the revised rents the value of Buildings erected by Lessees will Not be regarded as a ground for Increase of Rent

Example: If a plot is leased for a term of 80 years from 1st January 1907 then on the expiration of that term the Lessee will have a right (subject to observance of his covenant etc to obtain a fresh lease for a further period of 80 years at a revised rent, and so on in perpetuity. The revised rent will be calculated on the value-the site would bear if it were vacant building lands. Offers are invited of Premiums for the Purchase of the above mentioned leasehold sites.
All offers must be made by Tender, on the forms issued by the Sudan Government, and must be received at Khartoum not later than Ist January 1907.

Particulars of the sites offered, Plan of the Town, Conditions of Tender and Sale, Form of Tender, specimen Form of Lease, etc., will on and after October 1st 1906 be open to inspection at the following places during the usual business hours : Khartoum : *Office of Director of Agriculture and Lands (T) and Office of Governor of Khartoum Province. Cairo: *Office of Sudan Agent (T). - Port Sudan: Office of Inspector (Government Office) (T). Suakin: Office of Governor of Red Sea Province. El Damer: Office of Governor of Berber Province. Atbara : Office of Director of Railways. Alexandria : Office of Mr. Macpherson Grant. Port Said: Office of Dixon Bey, War Office Representative. London : *Office of Col. Western, Broadway Chambers, Westminster, and the Sudan
Court, Imperial Institute. Suez: Office of Capt. Falconer, War Office

Representative. For the convenience of intending purchasers the Conditions of Tender and Sale have been translated into Arabic and French and copies of the translations into either language will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. per copy at the Offices in the above list which are distinguished by a capital T. Further information will be obtainable after the publication of the above-mentioned documents on application in writing to The Director of Agriculture and Lands, Khartoum.
Copies of the Documents will be obtainable after 1st October 1906 on payment of 5 P.T. or 1 Shilling Iper copy at the Offices marked with an asterisk.

div.head: GOVERNMENT DU SUDAN
div.p: Concessions de Terrains a Batir a Port-Soudan
AVIS
Le Gouvernement du Soudan va prochaine. ment disposer, par voie d'adjudication d'environ 400 parcelles de terrains à bâtir à PortSoudan.

Les dites parcelles seront données à bail emphytéotique, pour une durée de 80 années å. partir du 1er Janvier 1907, moyennant loyer annuel, à charge pour le locataire de bâtir, Le loyer ne sera payable qu'à partir de la date de l'acceptation de l'offre.
Les baux seront renouvelables å perpétuité moyennant un loyer variable fixé à la fin de chaque terme, soit d'accord, soit par arbitrage.
En fixant le nouveau loyer, la valeur des bâtiments élevés par le locataire ne sera pas considéré comme un motif d'augmenta 'ion de loyer.

EXEMPLE: Si une parcelle de terrain est louée pour une durée de 80 années à partir du ler Janvier 1907. Dans ce cas, à l'expiration de ce dele, le locataire aura un droit (à condition d'observer les conditions du bail) d'obtenir un nouveau bail pour une nouvelle période de 80 années, moyennant un loyer modifié, et ainsi å perpétuité.
Le loger modifié sera calculé sur la valeur du terrain, 'il était libre de construction

Des ofres sont demandées pour les baux emphyt ptiques dont s'agit; ces offres devront mention ner la prime que le soumissionaire est disposé à payer au comptant en sus des loyers annuels établis pour chacun des lots. La dite prime devra être payée en un seul versement å la signature du contrat de bail.
Toutes'offres doivent être faites par soumission sur les formules dressées par le Gouvernemert du Soudan, et doivent être reçues à Khartoum avant le ler Janvier 1907.

Le détail des terrains offerts, le plan de la ville, les conditions de l'adjudication et de la concession, la formule de soumission, spécifica. tion du bail, seront à la disposition du Public à partir du Ter Octobre 1906, aux lieux ci-aprei indiqués, durant les heures de bureau.
Khartoum—Bureau du Directeur de l'A. griculture et des Terrains (T) et bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Khartoum.
Le Caire Bureau de l'agent du Gouvernement du Soudan (T).
Port-Soudan Bureau de l'Inspecteur (Bureau du Gouvernement (T).
Souakim-- Bureau du Gouverneur de la Pro.. vince et de la Mer Rouge.
Wadi-Halfa-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Halfa.
El-Damer-Bureau du Gouverneur de la Province de Berber..
Atbara --Bureau du Directeur du Chemin de Fer.
Alexandrie --Bureau de Mr. Macpherson Grant.
Port-Said —Bureau de F. Dixon bey, Representant du Ministère de la Guerre.
Londres Bureau du Colonel Western. Broadway Chambers, Westminster et lo Soudan Court, Imperial Institute.
Suez--Bureau du Capitaine Falconer, Roprésentant du Ministère de la Guerre.

Pour la con fité des acheteurs éventuels, les conditions dedication et de concession, Jont été traduilen arabe et en français et des copies de ces traductions, dans les deux langues, peuvent être obtenues à partir du ler Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T. 5 par copie, aux bureaux mentionnés dans la liste ci-dessus, qui sont suivis d'une lettre majuscule T. 1 Des informations, supplémentaires peuvent être obtenues après publications des documents ci-dessus mentionnés, moyennant demande écrite adressée au Directeur de l'Agriculture et des Terrains, à Khartoum..
Aux bureaux marqués d'uno astérisque, copies des documents pourront étre obtenues À partir du 12 Octobre 1906, moyennant payement de P.T o ou un shelling par copie.
